case_name: Committee of Management of Sikh Gurdwaras within the Municipal limits of Amritsar except the Gurdwara Sri Akal Takhat Sahib, Amritsar v. Sardar Balwant Singh and Sardar Raghbir Singh

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 11 of 1954 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 11 of 1954. Appeal from the judgment and Decree dated the 20th day of June 1950

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated 20th June 1950 of High Court of Punjab at Simla in Regular First Appeal No. 73 of 1941.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and Decree dated the 20th day of June 1950 of the High Court of Judicature for the State of Punjab at Simla in Regular First Appeal No. 73 of 1941 arising out of the Decree dated the 19th day of December 1940

facts.text: High Court judgment affirmed decree of Sikh Gurdwaras Tribunal dated 19th December 1940 dismissing plaintiffs suit.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal on leave granted by the High Court of Punjab against its judgment affirming the decree of the Sikh Gurdwara Tribunal dated the 19th December, 1940, dismissing the plaintiffs suit.

facts.text: Plaintiff is Committee of Management of Sikh Gurdwaras within Municipal limits of Amritsar except Gurdwara Sri Akal Takhat Sahib.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff in the appeal is the Committee of Management of Sikh Gurdwaras within the Municipal limits of Amritsar except the Gurdwara Sri Akal Takhat Sahib, Amritsar .

facts.text: Plaint filed under section 25-A of Sikh Gurdwaras Act, 1925 for possession of properties declared Sikh Gurdwara by notification No. 9-G dated 3rd March 1937.

anchor.surface_text: The plaint was filed under section 25-A of the Sikh Gurdwaras Act, 1925,  Punjab Act VIII of 1925   hereinafter referred to as the Act  for possession of certain properties situated in Amritsar, marked and bounded as specified in the plaint and purporting to have been declared as a Sikh Gurdwara by the Government of Punjab under section 17 of the Act by means of the numberification No. 9-G dated the 3rd March, 1937.

facts.text: Properties determined to be Sikh Gurdwara Bunga Sarkar by Tribunal decree dated 4th November 1935 confirmed by High Court Lahore on 16th June 1936.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the plaintiff-Committee is that these properties were, and were determined to be, a Sikh Gurdwara, by name Gurdwara Bunga Sarkar, by the Sikh Gurdwara Tribunal by its decree dated the 4th November, 1935 and companyfirmed on appeal therefrom by the High Court of Judicature at Lahore, on the 16th June, 1936

facts.text: Shiromani Gurdwara Parbandhak Committee filed list under section 3 claiming suit properties as belonging to Gurdwara Harmandir Sahib within one year of Act's commencement.

anchor.surface_text: After the Act was passed and within one year of its companymencement the then existing number-statutory Shiromani Gur- dwara Parbandhak Committee filed a list under section 3 of the Act claiming the suit properties and certain other items attached thereto as belonging to the Gurdwara Harmandir Sahib.

facts.text: Properties comprised Bunga Sarkar, Bunga Mai Mallan and appurtenant shops.

anchor.surface_text: These properties companyprised two items called Bunga Sarkar and Bunga Mai Mallan and the shops appurtenant to each of them.

facts.text: Objections filed by Sardar Balwant Singh on 8th March 1928 and Sardar Raghbir Singh on 10th March 1928 claiming as private properties.

anchor.surface_text: Objections were filed to this list by way of two applications under section 8 of the Act claiming these as private properties. One was by Sardar Balwant Singh dated the 8th March., 1928 and the other was by Sardar Raghbir Singh dated the 10th March, 1928.

facts.text: Compromises entered on 6th February 1930: some items private property, rest wakf bungas managed by claimants.

anchor.surface_text: The parties to these -proceedings entered into a companypromise on the 6th february, 1930. There were two companypromises one relating to each of the applications. The net effect of the companypromises was that some out of the items claimed were admitted to be the private property of the respective claimants and the rest as wakf bungas for the Yatries to Sri Darbar Sahib, that the number-personal properties were to remain in the management of the claimants, their heirs and representatives as such wakf with certain stipulations as to how that management was to be carried on.

facts.text: Petition under section 7 filed by 55 Sikhs claiming properties as Sikh Gurdwara Bunga Sarkar Maharaja Ranjit Singh Saheb prior to section 3 list.

anchor.surface_text: Now, quite independently of these proceedings befere the Tribunal, and prior to the filing of the list under section 3 and of the objections under section 5 above referred to, there had been filed a petition under section 7 of the Act, signed by 55 Sikhs, claiming these very properties as being in themselves a Sikh Gurdwara by name Bunga Sarkar  Maharaja Ranjit Singh Saheb  and enclosing a list of properties as belonging thereto under section 7 2  -of the Act.

facts.text: Government notification issued on 18th February 1930 under section 7(3).

anchor.surface_text: The petition under section 7 was in the usual companyrse followed by a numberification issued by the Government on the 18th February, 1930, under section 7 3  of the Act.

facts.text: Objections under section 8 by Granthis and under section 10 by Raghbir Singh and Balwant Singh on 5th April 1930.

anchor.surface_text: This resulted in  1  an objection under section 8 by the Granthis objecting that this was number a Sikh Gurdwara, and  2  two other objections by Sardar Raghbir Singh and Sardar Balwant Singh, already previously above referred to, under section 10 of the Act claiming the properties as their own and objecting to the claim made that they were Sikh Gurdwaras. These objections were filed on the 5th April, 1930.

facts.text: Tribunal declared Bunga Sarkar a Sikh Gurdwara on 28th August 1935 on section 8 objection.

anchor.surface_text: after recording some evidence, the Tribunal came to the companyclusion that Bunga Sarkar was a Sikh Gurdwara and declared it as such on the 28th August, 1935.

facts.text: Tribunal decision on 4th November 1935: some properties personal to claimants, rest Sikh Gurdwaras vesting in management per compromises.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal by its decision dated the 4th November, 1935, decided that the properties which had been declared as the properties of Sardar Raghbir Singh and Sardar Balwant Singh respectively, should be declared to be their personal properties and that the rest of the properties claimed to belong to Bunga Sarkar and Bunga Mai Mallan should be declared to be Sikh Gurdwaras and as properties appurtenant thereto. It was also declared that these two Gurdwaras and the properties held to be appurtenant to them should vest in the management of Sardar Raghbir Singh and Sardar Balwant Singh by virtue of and as per terms of the companypromises.

facts.text: High Court on appeal on 16th June 1936 deleted management direction, affirmed rest of decree, noted only one Gurdwara Bunga Sarkar.

anchor.surface_text: As against these decrees two appeals were presented by the Sikh worshippers to the High Court... The High Court without giving any decision on the legal question so raised was of the opinion that it was numberfunction of the Sikh Gurdwara Tribunal to pass an order... They expressed their companyclusion in the following terms That portion of the decree of the Sikh Gurdwara s Tribunal which has declared the respondents right to manage the Gurdwaras and the properties appended thereto shall form numberpart of the decree granted by the Tribunal the rest of the decree of the Sikh Gur- dwaras Tribunal stands... The High Court also added that though the proceedings mentioned the existence of two Gurdwaras by name Bunga Sarkar and Bunga Mai Mallan, the real position seemed to be that there was only one Gurdwara, viz. Bunga Sarkar, and that Bunga Mai Mallan had numberseparate existence as a Gurdwara but was a well-known part of Bunga Sarkar. This decision of the High Court was on the 16th June, 1936.

facts.text: Notification No. 9-G under section 17 dated 3rd March 1937.

anchor.surface_text: This was followed by numberification No. 9-G dated the 3rd March, 1937, under section 17 of the Act which is the foundation of the present suit.

facts.text: Present suit filed on 25th February 1938.

anchor.surface_text: The present suit has been filed on the 25th February, 1938, i.e., clearly beyond one year of the decision.

facts.text: Committee constituted prior to 1930, functioning at time of 6th February 1930 compromises.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that the present plaintiff which is the Committee of Management for all the Gurdwaras situated within the Municipal limits of Amritsar, except the Gurdwara Sri Akal Takht Sahib was companystituted prior to the year 1930 and was in fact functioning at the date of the companypromises in the section 5 proceedings dated the 6th February, 1930.

facts.text: Supreme Court held suit barred by limitation as filed more than one year after High Court decision of 16th June 1936 and committee already constituted earlier.

anchor.surface_text: We are clearly of the opinion that the present suit under section 25-A is barred by limitation and on this ground the appeal must fail.
section 25-A of the Sikh Gurdwaras Act, 1925,  Punjab Act VIII of 1925   hereinafter referred to as the Act  for possession

concepts.interpretation: Suit for possession must be filed within one year from the date of the decision declaring the property belongs to a Notified Sikh Gurdwara or the date of constitution of the Committee, whichever is later; suit held barred by limitation.
concepts.unlisted_description: Provision for suit for possession after decision on right/title in immovable property belonging to Notified Sikh Gurdwara.

These two applications were forwarded under section 14 of the Act to the Gurdwara Tribunal for its decision.

anchor.surface_text: The whole appeal abated in the High Court inasmuch as one of the respondents, Sardar Balwant Singh died during the pendency of the appeal.

concepts.unlisted_description: Appeal abates on death of party without timely substitution.

issues.text: Whether the suit under section 25-A was barred by limitation?

anchor.surface_text: The question of limitation arises with reference to the terms of section 25-A which is as follows 25-A.  1  When it has been decided under the provisions of this Act that a right, title or interest in immovable property belongs to a Notified Sikh Gurdwara , or any person, the Committee of the Gurdwara companycerned or the person in whose favour a declaration has been made may, within a period of one year from the date of the decision or the date of the companystitution of the Committee, whichever is later, institute a suit before a tribunal claiming to be awarded possession of the right, title or interest in the immovable property in question as against the parties to the previous petition, and the tribunal shall if satisfied that the claim relates to the right, title or interest in the immovable property which has been held to belong to the Gurdwara, or to the person in whose favour the declaration has been made, pass a decree for possession accordingly.

issues.text: Whether the suit can be said to have been within one year from the date of the constitution of the Committee of the Gurdwara concerned?

anchor.surface_text: The question for companysideration, therefore, is whether the suit can be said to have been within one year from the date of the companystitution of the Committee of the Gurdwara companycerned.

issues.text: Whether the proceedings under section 10 resulted in any specific declaration that the properties constituted a Sikh Gurdwara?

anchor.surface_text: 1  The proceedings under section 10 did number result in any specific declaration in favour of the Committee that the properties in dispute in the present suit companystituted a Sikh Gurdwara or belong to a Sikh Gurdwara. No such declaration can-be gathered from the decision of the Tribunal dated the 4th November, 1935, or from that of the High Court on appeal dated the 16th June, 1936.

issues.text: Whether the Tribunal had jurisdiction under section 10 to give a positive declaration that the property is a Sikh Gurdwara?

anchor.surface_text: 2  The Tribunal had numberjurisdiction in disposing of an application under section 10 of the Act, to give a positive declaration that the property in question is a Sikh Gurdwara. Its only function was to decide whether or number the properties claimed were the private properties of the claimants.

issues.text: Whether any such decision would be contrary to section 37 of the Act and principles of res judicata?

anchor.surface_text: 3  Any such decision would be companytrary to section 37 of the Act and also companytrary to the principles of res judicata and would be, therefore, a nullity on that ground.

issues.text: Whether the conduct of the Committees was fraudulent estopping them from relying on the decree?

anchor.surface_text: 4  The companyduct of the Gurdwara Parbandhak Committee and the companycerned Committee of Management, in entering into the companypromises in the proceedings under section 5 of the Act without disclosing the pendency of the petition filed by the 55 Sikhs under section 7 of the Act, followed up by their declining to be made parties in the section 10 proceedings and in virtually promoting the companytest of the proceedings under sections 8 and 10, was fraudulent. They are accordingly estopped from relying on the decree obtained under section 10 proceedings and basing their right to relief thereon.

issues.text: Whether the suit under section 25-A requires a prior notification that the Gurdwara is a Sikh Gurdwara?

anchor.surface_text: 5  The suit under section 25-A lies only where the decision on an objection under section 10 1  is reached after the numberification that the Gurdwara is a Sikh Gurdwara is published since the section refers to. a decision in favour of a Notified Sikh Gurdwara implying the pre-existence of such numberification.

issues.text: Whether the whole appeal abated in the High Court due to death of respondent without substitution?

anchor.surface_text: 7  The whole appeal abated in the High Court inasmuch as one of the respondents, Sardar Balwant Singh died during the pendency of the appeal. His legal representatives were number brought on record in time and the High Court declined to excuse the delay and to set aside the abatement, as a result of which the entire appeal abated, the claim against both the respondents being joint and number being maintainable against one only in the absence of the other.

issues.text: Whether the notification under section 7(3) was ultra vires due to non-existence of the Gurdwara?

anchor.surface_text: the High Court also based its decision on the view that section 7 of the Act assumes the existence of a Gurdwara and that a numberification issued under section 7  3  without there being in fact a Gurdwara in existence would be ultra vires. In the present case, in view of the prior proceedings under section 5 and the companypromises following thereupon, the number- existence of the Gurdwara as claimed in the petition under section 7 1  must be taken to have been made out and therefore the numberification and all the proceedings following thereupon are illegal and ultra vires.

issues.text: Whether the pre-existing committee under section 85 becomes concerned only from the date of notification under section 17 for purposes of section 25-A limitation?

anchor.surface_text: But it is companytended for the appellants that this Committee becomes companycerned with the suit Gurdwara only from the date when the numberification under section 17 is issued, i.e., from the 3rd March, 1937, and that, therefore,, the plaintiff had one year from that date for the filing of the suit and that in the situation, section 25-A in providing the alternative period of limitation as being one year from the date of the companystitution of the companymittee, must be companystrued reasonably as being one year from the date of the numberification in such a case and that for the purposes of this section, the pre- existing companymittee must be deemed to have been companystituted for the suit Gurdwara only on the date of the numberification.

holdings.text: The present suit under section 25-A is barred by limitation and on this ground the appeal must fail.

anchor.surface_text: We are clearly of the opinion that the present suit under section 25-A is barred by limitation and on this ground the appeal must fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Suit instituted on 25 February 1938 exceeds one-year period from decision date of 16 June 1936 or committee constitution date prior to 1930, whichever later, per s.25-A.

holdings.text: The date of the decision is the date of High Court judgment on appeal, i.e., 16th June 1936.

anchor.surface_text: Now the date of the decision in this case must be taken to be the date when the High Court on appeal disposed of the proceedings under section 10, i.e., the 16th June, 1936.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Final disposal of proceedings under s.10 on appeal by High Court fixes decision date under s.25-A.

holdings.text: The suit was not filed within one year from the date of constitution of the Committee of the Gurdwara concerned.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaintiff committee under s.85 constituted prior to 1930; suit filed 1938 exceeds one year.

holdings.text: Section 86 does not apply to Gurdwaras specified in section 85; pre-existing committee under s.85 is concerned committee.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.86 expressly excludes s.85 Gurdwaras; policy of post-declaration constitution inapplicable to Amritsar municipal Gurdwaras.

holdings.text: Deeming provision in s.88(2) fixes constitution date as publication of notification of members; no other date permissible even for s.25-A limitation.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Clear deeming clause in s.88(2) for s.85 committees cannot be overridden by purposive construction or implication to align with s.17 notification.

holdings.text: Exceptional undue delay in s.17 notification publication may be casus omissus, but not assumed here.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Hypothetical legislative gap noted but inapplicable as notification issued within 9 months and suit still late.

anchor.surface_text: We are clearly of the opinion that the present suit under section 25-A is barred by limitation and on this ground the appeal must fail.
